text.headline: Overview
text.text:
The Lightning Network is a scaling solution for Bitcoin, based on payment channels. While the latter were already conceived by Satoshi Nakamoto, the Lightning Network and its key components arose from the Bitcoin community itself, with many people sharing their thoughts and ideas along the way.

This timeline aims to summarize the corner points of the development of the Lightning Network from Bitcoin's inception up to the present state of the network.

text.headline: Satoshi's payment channels
text.text:
Ideas about payment channels (a fundamental building block of the Lightning Network) are almost as old as Bitcoin itself, as they were already considered by Satoshi Nakamoto.

Satoshi's design for payment channels was however not entirely trustless; a user could collude with miners to have an old channel state confirmed, and thus cheat on the channel-counterparty.

text.headline: Making payment channels fully trustless
text.text: bitcointalk.org user "hashcoin" proposed that channel participants could exchange partially signed multisignature transactions and transactions with timelocks to make payment channels resistant against miner collusion attacks.

text.headline: Payment network concepts
text.text:
Many more ideas and concepts emerged from the Bitcoin community during the following years, from people like Corn√© Plooy, Meni Rosenfeld, Jeremy Spillman, Alex Akselrod, Christian Decker and Roger Wattenhofer and others.

You can find more details in this article.

media.caption: Joseph Poon presents the ideas of the paper in March 2015

text.headline: "The Bitcoin Lightning Network" paper released
text.text:
Joseph Poon and Thaddeus Dryja release the paper which later on would often be referred to as the Lightning Network white paper.

While the paper was published as work in progress, the proposed use of Hashed Timelock Contracts for routing payments over multiple channels turned out to be a game-changer.

text.headline: First commit on Blockstream's "c-lightning"
text.text:
After having written a series of blog posts to educate about the ideas behind the Lightning Network, long-time Linux kernel developer Rusty Russell joined Blockstream to start the first implementation of the Lightning Network. It is written in the C programming language and hence called c-lightning.

This event was pivotal not only because the Lightning Network started to move from a concept to reality, but also because this was done by a world-class developer.

Later on he would be joined by Christian Decker, a long-time Bitcoin developer.

text.headline: First commit on ACINQ's "Eclair"
text.text:
Fabrice Drouin, a developer from the French startup ACINQ pushed the first commit of a new Lightning implementation called "Eclair" onto Github. Eclair is written in Scala.

ACINQ was consequently the second company working on an implementation of the Lightning Network protocol, and the first one to work exclusively on Lightning.

ACINQ had a big impact on building the Lightning Network community by providing working and user-friendly software early on. This includes solutions like their Android wallet and their virtual coffee shop called Starblocks.

text.headline: First commit on Lightning Labs' "LND"
text.text:
Olaoluwa "Roasbeef" Osuntokun, CTO and Co-founder of Lightning Labs pushed the first commit of a new Lightning implementation called "LND" onto Github.

LND is an abbreviation for "Lightning Network Daemon" and is written in Go.

Lightning Labs was the third company working on an own implementation of the Lightning Network protocol. Together with Blockstream and ACINQ, these were the companies that were to become the main protagonists in bootstrapping the Lightning Network protocol in the following years.

text.headline: Most recent version of paper released
text.text: The paper "The Bitcoin Lightning Network" was released in its most recent form, namely the DRAFT Version 0.5.9.2

media.caption: The image that Christian Decker bought from Rusty Russell

text.headline: First purchase on the Bitcoin testnet
text.text:
Christian Decker, c-lightning developer at Blockstream, made the first Lightning payment (on the Bitcoin testnet). He bought a cat picture from fellow developer Rusty Russell for 100 satoshis.

The payment was first performed directly between two nodes, and after that even with another node in between forwarding the payment.

According to Blockstream, this was "the first end-to-end test of a lightning micropayment network, including invoicing, multi-hop payment, and item delivery."

text.headline: Lightning Spec Summit 1.0
text.text:
Since the Lightning Network is not the product of one single company but quite to the contrary a true grassroots movement that has emerged from the Bitcoin community, it is important that the different contributors coordinate and set standards. And that's exactly what happened for the first time, at the Lightning Network spec 1.0 in Milan.

The outcome of the summit set the foundation for interoperability between the different implementations. It included topics like transaction formats, the routing protocol (including onion routing), finding consensus on the naming of various protocol components, defining port numbers and the derivation of commitment hashes.

text.headline: The RGB protocol was proposed
text.text: The RGB protocol was proposed by Peter Todd and Giacomo Zucco in 2016. The goal of RGB is to serve as a second, or even third, layer protocol that is based either directly on Bitcoin or on the Lightning Network. It enables the creation of smart contracts without the limitations inherent in any blockchain structure.

text.headline: SegWit activates
text.text:
Segregated Witness activated on the Bitcoin blockchain at block 481,824 as a soft fork.

This consensus relevant update was an important acquirement for the Lightning Network, since it solved an issue known as transaction malleability, which was a fundamental precondition for implementing the Lightning Network.

This consensus change had be in the working for a long time and was subject to a lot of controversy, which ended in it being forced upon its enemies in a user activated soft fork.

media.caption: The first physical good bought over Lightning: A router

text.headline: First ever physical purchase over Lightning
text.text:
The future is now - that's what Reddit user btc_throwaway1337 must have thought when he bought his new router. This was the first ever purchase of a physical good over the Mainnet Lightning Network. His wallet of choice was LND.

He summarized his experience with the following words: "It was all quick, easy, painless, and most importantly: instantaneous and fee-free!"

text.headline: Launch of the Blockstream Store
text.text:
The Blockstream Store was a very early Lightning enabled store, created with the aim to "provide a way for you to test Lightning and become a part of the micropayment revolution", as described in Blockstream's announcement.

The store was selling stickers and t-shirts and was only accepting Lightning payments (at first).

At the time the Lightning Network and it's implementations were still seen as highly unstable, such that Blockstream developer Rusty Russell warned people that it would be reckless to use their own shop. This was the birth of the #reckless-hashtag, which became a popular self-description for early adopters of the Lightning Network.

media.caption: Laszlo with his family and the ordered Pizzas

text.headline: Laszlo buys Pizzas - again!
text.text:
Laszlo Hanyecz, the guy who famously bought 2 Pizzas for 10'000 BTC in 2010 striked again!

Reckless as he is, he once again bought two Pizzas for Bitcoin ‚Äì this time over the Lightning Network, paying 649'000 satoshis.

Laszlo documented the event pretty well and you may read a summary about it or look at his pictures. Notice the t-shirts of his sons when doing so ;-)

media.caption: Elisabeth Stark's tweet about the launch of the network

text.headline: Lightning goes live on Bitcoin mainnet!
text.text: Lightning Labs were the first to officially support the Bitcoin mainnet with the release of LND 0.4-beta. However, even if all previous versions of all Lightning implementations were considered as not yet ready for mainnet, at the time of the release there were already around 1'000 Lightning nodes operating on mainnet.

media.caption: Peter Todd concerned about DoS vulnerability of Lightning Network, one month prior to the attack

text.headline: DDoS Attack
text.text:
A Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack took down around 200 Lightning Network nodes. At the time this was about 20% of the network, reducing its online nodes count from around 1,050 to 870.

About one month before, cryptographer Peter Todd was warning that the Lightning Network is vulnerable to such an attack in the current state [of that point in time].

text.headline: Lightning Network liquidity tops 10 BTC
text.text: The Lightning Network liquidity of the visible network [ = announced channels only ] moved over 10 BTC for the first time, distributed in over 4'800 channels belonging to more than 1'100 nodes.

text.headline: First Lightning Network Hackday
text.text:
The first of a series of "Hackdays" took place in Berlin with about 100 attendees.

The event was not mainly focused on the development of the Lightning Network protocol, but rather on building tools and applications that make use of it.

The hackday was such a success, that Fulmo organized more of these events, 3 of them in the very same year.

media.caption: The Lightning Stack. Eltoo is a proposal that only concerns the updating mechanism.

text.headline: Eltoo paper gets published
text.text:
Christian Decker announced and released a paper about a new update mechanism for Lightning called eltoo. *

Even though eltoo is popular amongst the Lightning community, it has not yet been implemented because it requires a new SIGHASH called SIGHASH_NOINPUT on Bitcoin, which can only be implemented through a Soft Fork. For this reason, Decker has uploaded a first draft of a proposal to integrate SIGHASH_NOINPUT (BIP 118) on the very same day.

While eltoo is poised to make many problems in Lightning a lot easier (e.g. channel state backups or watchtowers), critics are concerned about the lack of strong disincentives for malicious actors to propose old channel states.

* The name eltoo is derived from the English pronunciation of the letters "L2", which itself is an abbreviation for "Layer 2".
  The Lightning Network is often referred to as a second layer solution for Bitcoin, building on its first layer which is Bitcoin's consensus mechanism on the blockchain level.

media.caption: Satoshi's place: Timelapse of the first few weeks (NSFW)

text.headline: satoshis.place goes online
text.text:
One of the most popular websites of the early days of the Lightning Network went online: Satoshi's Place.

Inspired by the Million Dollar Homepage, it lets you color pixels at a price of 1 Satoshi/pixel. The given pixels are then shown in the chosen color on satoshis.place until they get overwritten by somebody else purchasing them.

This playful website developed by Lightning K0ala rapidly grew in popularity and showed to the world that the Lightning Network was not only working, but also being used by people all over the world.

text.headline: Lightning Network liquidity tops 100 BTC
text.text: The Lightning Network liquidity of the visible network [ = announced channels only ] moved over 100 BTC for the first time, distributed in over 8'400 channels belonging to more than 2'400 nodes.

text.headline: Anonymous player boosts network liquidity
text.text:
The Lightning Network liquidity of the visible network [ = announced channels only ] was around 110 BTC, when suddenly an unknown person or group put 20 new Lightning nodes online, which collectively provided the Lightning Network with an additional liquidity of over 350 BTC in a very short time period.

All these nodes had similar aliases; they started with the letters "LNBIG.com". Later on, the website lnbig.com was launched, where you could find the addresses of all the respective nodes.

text.headline: The Lightning Torch
text.text:
Twitter user @hodlonaut started a chain, by offering someone trustworthy 100,000 Satoshis, if this person would then forward this payment plus 10,000 more Satoshis to a trustworthy person of his own choosing. The next user should then also play along, passing the Satoshis from user to user as is if it was a torch. The experiment quickly became a phenomenon in the Bitcoin community with many people participating in it, like for example the Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey himself.

Many people saw the Lightning Torch as an effective showcase for how seamlessly Lightning payments could be sent around the world, in a time when the Lightning Network was still in it's infancy and seldomly used.

The #LNTrustChain ended 291 handovers later, when Twitter user @btcven proclaimed he would use the resulting 4,29 million Satoshis as humanitarian aid for Venezuelans.

Find more details on this website.

text.headline: The LNP/BP Standards Association was officially founded
text.text: In 2019, the LNP/BP Standards Association was officially founded by Maxim Orlovsky and Giacomo Zucco. The primary goal of the association is to establish open standards and best practices for the second and third layer protocols for Bitcoin and the Lightning Network, introducing smart contracts to the Lightning Network and BTC. Subsequently, the association proposed the BP Node.

media.caption: The LNP Node was officially released

text.headline: The LNP Node was officially released
text.text: In 2021, the LNP Node was officially released by the LNP/BP Standards Association, aimed at achieving the "Generalized Lightning Network." Its main uses include the modular design of payment channels, developer tools, and DEX.

text.headline: Storm Core was officially released
text.text: In 2022, the Storm Core was officially released by the LNP/BP Standards Association. Storm is a storage and messaging layer 3 on top of the Bitcoin and Lightning Network. This library provides core components for building Storm LNP channels and applications.

text.headline: RGB v0.10 alpha1 was released
text.text: In Mar 2023, version 0.10 of RGB was officially released, marking the advent of the smart contract era on the Lightning Network.

text.headline: Bitlght wallet was released
text.text: In April 2024, the first user-oriented wallet supporting Lightning Network and RGB smart contracts, Bitlight Wallet, was released by Bitlight Labs. Bitlight Labs is committed to accelerating the evolution of the Lightning Network and Bitcoin ecosystem.
